thread.title: Man dies after loader accident at Bluff port
thread.title_full: Man dies after loader accident at Bluff port

title: Man dies after loader accident at Bluff port
text:
Man dies after loader accident at Bluff port Last updated 10:58, February 24 2017 
Emergency services were called at around 1.45am after reports of a worker being run over by a loader, police said. 
A man has died in an early-morning workplace accident at South Port, Bluff. 
Emergency services were called about 1.45am after reports of a worker being run over by a loader, police said. 
The 54-year-old man died at the scene a short time later. 
Worksafe NZ was investigating. 
A WorkSafe spokeswoman said the organisation was notified of the incident, which involced a loader and a truck, and attended the scene overnight. 
They were unable to provide further information because an investigation was underway, she said. 
A police media spokeswoman said she was unable to confirm where the man was from, or which company he worked for. 
Police were assisting in the investigation, working with the family, and providing victim support services, she said. 
South Port chief executive Mark O'Connor said the man was not a South Port employee. 
A Fire Service spokesman said while they were called to the incident, they were stood down before they arrived. 
A St John Ambulance spokesman said they were alerted at 1.39am and sent two ambulances to the scene. 
"[The] patient was deceased at scene so not transported, sadly." 
South Port, at Bluff, is New Zealand's southernmost commercial deep water port. 
In 2015, 51-year-old Morrell McKenzie, a Bluff businessman, died after the truck he was in went over the edge of the wharf and into the water at South Port.
